chapter.title: Migration from &yast1; and &alice;
chapter.para: ALICE, SuSE's former auto-installation system was a system built around the auto-installation features that were available with &yast1;. In order to able to use existing ALICE configuration files and resources, a special package is provided which will enable you to convert ALICE system configuration files into a control file readable by &autoyast2; using the configuration management system.

sect1.title: Interface with &yast1; and &alice;
sect1.para: &alice; uses &yast1; for the installation of the Linux System. This is done by creating a boot medium with the needed control file (info) from a set of configuration files maintained in a CVS repository. The info file has the traditional format used with &yast1;.

sect1.title: System Configuration with &alice;
sect1.para: The system configuration is done almost entirely after the system is installed and is initiated as the %post section of the &alice; RPM package.

sect2.title: &alice; modules
sect2.para: Each of ALICE modules perform certain tasks and requires one or multiple configuration files. The modules are shell scripts that are envoked after installation of the machine to set different things up.

&yast2; offers an extensive and rich interface to the installed system which replaces most of these modules available with &alice; The following is a list of all &alice; modules, their function and how their functionality is provided by &yast2; modules which are already available or which can be integrated easily:

The modules prepare_alice and make_all provided the base and main scripts of all &alice; modules. The module prepare_alice is called right after the initial installation process - which is done after &yast1; is finished with the basic installation.

With &yast2;, the alternative to these modules is part of the system and is not an addition or extension. This means that &yast2; configures the system in one single process and not, as with &alice; in two different, independent steps.

sect2.title: Other configuration options with &yast2; and &alice;
sect2.para: Entries in /etc/sysconfig can be easily set and modified using &yast2;. For network services it is recommended to use the relevant &yast2; modules dealing with networking , rather than modifying /etc/sysconfig/network directly.
